the code does not work correctly, the translation is not applied correctly, and the modules do not keep angular offsets post power-cycle. I programmed swerve last year, and have no idea what’s going on.

Just to throw this out there: if your swerve drives aren’t staying tuned for very long it is worthwhile to double check if the encoder sensor magnet in each individual swerve drive is glued securely into the socket. If the magnet rotates freely, the absolute encoders will not understand where they are and the robots understanding of “forward” will change. It happened to my students a few years back and is a pretty common issue.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2025-02-11T03:13:25.700Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":14,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":28,"readers_count":27,"score":5.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":485693,"topic_slug":"mk4i-code-doesnt-work","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":62391,"username":"Zaheelee","name":"Jessie Adkins","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/z/3e96dc/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58360,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/mk4i-code-doesnt-work/485693/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3523093,"name":"Jason Evans","username":"j.e","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/j.e/{size}/175324_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-11T05:15:26.108Z","cooked":"

I was worried that whatever problem you hit in DutyCycleEncoder could also cause problems for our use of DutyCycle with a time-of-flight sensor, so I poked around to better understand the issue. We’re not affected (because we only query pulse length), but I think I see why you are. See the DutyCycleEncoder.setAssumedFrequency() docs as a starting point:

/**
   * Sets the assumed frequency of the connected device.
   *
   * <p>By default, the DutyCycle engine has to compute the frequency of the input signal. This can
   * result in both delayed readings and jumpy readings. To solve this, you can pass the expected
   * frequency of the sensor to this function. This will use that frequency to compute the DutyCycle
   * percentage, rather than the computed frequency.
   *
   * @param frequency the assumed frequency of the sensor
   */

The problem is that deep in the bowels of an NI library (for which I didn’t find source code), a rolling(?) window of state transition counts is maintained, and it is presumably used internally to estimate the pulse frequency. Duty cycles are calculated as the length of the most recent pulse divided by the cycle length. The NI library is apparently giving bad information about the duty cycle, perhaps doing some iffy cycle counting/dividing math early on before it has seen many cycles.

But back to DutyCycleEncoder.setAssumedFrequency(). If you set the assumed frequency, DutyCycleEncoder divides the length of the most recent high pulse by the known cycle length, and you should get accurate values immediately. I didn’t find specs for the Thrifty encoder frequency, but it’s easy to get once from a quiesced DutyCycle instance via the getFrequency() method. Perhaps not a general solution for YAGSL if it’s dealing with a bunch of different PWM encoders, but if I were running YAGSL with that hardware, I’d certainly want to set the frequency and avoid the 2 second initialization wait.

[Edit] The Thrifty encoder is analog (voltage-based), so I was incorrect to associate it with duty cycles.

By default YAGSL only uses the absolute encoder at the start to keep low CAN utilization. So i would rather delay the code startup by a few seconds is safer. No match should start within 8secs of robot code start anyways
